comment.author: 59842170@N00
comment._content:
Look like it - 6 round cylinder of .45 calibre. There was a variant which held 8 rounds of .38 calibre. Impossible to know if they are manual or semi-automatic revolvers. 
Lewis Gun Pan holding 47 or 97 .303 round. These pans look to be 47 rd. Rate of fire 400-600 rpm [rounds per minute]

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Secret Destination--Passage West. Your photograph was taken ----looking for'ard---- aboard the TSS Arvonia. It was from this ship that Major-General Emmet Dalton successfully landed 456 men at Passage West on the 8th of August 1922. The TSS Arvonia( ex Cambria) plied between Dublin and Holyhead and was requisitioned from the London and North Western Railway Co.( L&NWR) specifically for the southern troop landings. Another ship, the TSS Lady Wicklow (requisitioned from the B & I and also at Passage West), was used on the Fenit landing on the 2nd August. The picture would date from late July/ early August 1922. I cannot see why it wouldn't have been taken on the voyage to Cork as the ship had only just been commandeered and also Hogan was in Passage West to see the troops disembark. He had to have been on board for the whole journey South. There are other photographs in the Hogan collection that support this and confirm that this one was taken aboard the Arvonia. Note name on bell "Cambria", anchor,windbreak,fair-lead and other details common to both pictures "Maj.Gen. Dalton's expeditionary force consisted of roughly 800 men supported by two Peerless and one Whippet armored car, and two 18 pdrs, along with several Lancia APCs. Some 200 of these troops were raw recruits who would receive rudimentary firearms training during the voyage".generalmichaelcollins.com/pages/irishcivilwar.html [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/9257271429/] .

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Very convincing argument! Thank you so much, have amended title, description, date and tags accordingly...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Hi. To be finicky--------- You mentioned above that the TSS Arvonia was "under the command of Major-General Emmet Dalton." This isn't quite right. The ship would have been under the command of her own Captain while Dalton was in overall command of the operation...It is not known who the ship's captain was at the time . Here he is though on the left of General Dalton and General Ennis with his first mate on the right. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000280448. There are a lot of photographs in the hogan collection that are wrongly recorded as being "on the Lady Wicklow"....and "loading" when in fact, off loading....we'll have to blame one of the 9 bosses :) The Arvonia and Lady Wicklow left North Wall Dublin for Cork on the 6th August so photograph taken on 6th, 7th or early morning of the 8th Aug. 1922. P.S TSS ---------Twin Screw Streamer.
